NB-mCherry (red) stained with DAPI. nullbasic-mCherry did not affect localization of GFP2 lacking a nuclear import signal. similar experiments indicated that coexpression of Myc-Rev with Nullbasic likewise had no effect on the nuclear localizations of the respective reporters. nucleocytoplasmic shuttling of Rev is critical for HIV-1 infectivity. nucleocytoplasmic shuttling of Rev requires coordinated transport of incompletely spliced viral mRNAs from the nucleus. nullbasic’s action in downregulating Rev’s mRNA transport function is therefore of great importance. our evidence strongly indicates that CRM1 is a mediator through which Nullbasic induces Rev redistribution. this was evident through the use of LMB (Fig. 3), a specific inhibitor of CRM1 and the RevM10 mutant, whose altered NES is no longer recognized or bound by CRM1. in both cases, Rev retained a nucleolar localization despite high levels of nullbasic expression. nullbasic did not affect the localizations of CRM1, B23 and C23 in the absence of Rev. it indicates that nullbasic is not inducing a generalized deformation or reconfiguration of cellular nucleoli. it is evident, therefore, that Nullbasic induces the redistribution of CRM1, B23 and C23 only in the presence of Rev. replication of certain DNA and RNA viruses requires the trafficking of viral proteins through the nucleolus [42]. in some instances, for example during herpes simplex virus and adenovirus infections, this results in the dramatic mislocalization of C23 and B23 [42], [49]. basic appears to interact with and disrupt specific components of a Rev trafficking complex required for Rev nucleocytoplasmic shuttling. cells were transfected to express Myc-Rev alone (row 1), Tat-FLAG alone (row 2), Nullbasic (NB)-FLAG alone (row 3), Myc-Rev with Tat-FLAG (row 4) or NB-FLAG (rows 5).
